newsitem.title: CHINA: Hopewell working on Thai rail financing.
newsitem.headline: Hopewell working on Thai rail financing.

text.p: Hopewell Holdings Ltd said on Friday it was continuing to work closely with bankers on a financing solution for its Bangkok mass transit project which will be presented to the Thai government in detail next month.
Hopewell reaffirmed its commitment to the Bangkok Elevated Road and Train System (BERTS) after a meeting with the State Railway of Thailand on Friday.
The company said meetings were held with bankers in Europe and London last week and good progress has been made, but added bankers require more time to conclude their financial planning.

Hopewell said it asked senior officials from the Bank Group to meet with the Thai government as soon as possible to confirm their commitment to the project, present the progress on the financing plan and timetable, and obtain views and suggestions.
The Bank Group includes Kreditanstalt fuer Wiederaufbau, Bayerische Landesbank, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, Westdeutsche Landesbank Group, and West Merchant Bank, it said.
Hopewell said it will meet separately with the government if requested.

The original schedule for the project financing has been affected by the decline of the economic climate in Thailand and the devaluation of the baht, and that funding for any project in Thailand is now harder, the company said.

Hopewell said despite various issues faced by the project, it strongly believes that financial closing can be achieved, and that it continued to work with the Bank Group on a solution which will be presented to the government in detail next month.
Hopewell earlier said it has received no formal deadline from the Thai government.

Sathien Wongvichien, Thailand's Deputy Permanent Secretary for Transport and Communications, said on July 24 that if Hopewell could not come up with a firm financing package by the end of July, the ministry could exercise its contractual right to scrap the 30-year BERTS operating concession awarded to Hopewell in 1990.

Hopewell Chairman Gordon Wu said on July 21 that the financing structure was in place, but added he did not want to take the money until Bangkok promised to clear land acquisition problems and agreed to a fare rise to cover increased costs.
On Friday, Standard and Poor's affirmed its BBB-minus corporate crdit rating on Hopewell and revised the outlook for the company to stable from negative.
The rating agency said Hopewell's sale of its power unit had allowed it to cut leverage and better focus on management of its existing portfolio and future investment commitments.
But the rating still reflected considerable uncertainty regarding the future of BERTS and its implementation, which helped reduce the potential for any upgrade, S&P said.
